m(q) be the probability measure uniformly supported on the cusp cross sections

Distribution of cusp sections in the Hilbert modular orbifold
Samuel Estala Arias

arXiv:1112.1146v1 [math.NT] 6 Dec 2011

Unidad Cuernavaca del Instituto de Matemáticas, Universidad Nacional Autónoma de México.
Av. Universidad s/n, Colonia Lomas de Chamilpa, C.P. 62210, Cuernavaca, Morelos, México

Abstract
Let K be a number field, let M be the Hilbert modular orbifold of K, and let mq be the
probability measure uniformly supported on the cusp cross sections of M at height q.
We generalize a method of Zagier and show that mq distributes uniformly with respect
to the normalized Haar measure m on M as q tends to zero, and relate the rate by which
mq approaches m to the Riemann hypothesis for the Dedekind zeta function of K.
Keywords: Hilbert modular orbifold, Eisenstein series, Dedekind zeta function

1. Introduction
Let H2 = {x + iy ∈ C : y > 0} be the Poincaré upper half-plane with the hyperbolic
metric ds2 = (dx2 + dy 2 )/2. The group P SL(2, R) acts on H2 by fractional linear
transformations which, as well, are hyperbolic isometries. The modular group Γ =
P SL(2, Z) is a discrete subgroup of P SL(2, R) and the quotient space H2 /Γ is the
classical modular orbifold. From the classification of horocycles it follows that for each
y > 0, the modular orbifold has a unique closed horocycle Cy of length y −1 . Let my be
the probability measure uniformly supported on Cy (w.r.t. arc length). Let m be the
normalized hyperbolic measure of H2 /Γ. We have the following well-known result due
to D. Zagier (cf. [22]).
Theorem 1. Let f be a smooth function on H2 /Γ with compact support. Then,
my (f ) = m(f ) + o(y 1/2−ǫ )

(y → 0)

for all 0 < ǫ < 1/2.
In particular, the measures my converge vaguely to m as y → 0. Besides, in [22] Zagier
establishes the following remarkable equivalence to the Riemann hypothesis.

 Theorem 2. The Riemann hypothesis holds if and only if for every smooth function f
with compact support on H2 /Γ one has
my (f ) = m(f ) + o(y 3/4−ǫ )

(y → 0)

for all 0 < ǫ < 3/4.
In the related work [14], P. Sarnak proved an analogue of these theorems for the unit
tangent bundle of the modular orbifold, which can be identified with the quotient space
P SL(2, R)/Γ. Likewise, in [19] A. Verjovsky has shown that the analogue estimate of
Theorem 1 in Sarnak's work is optimal for certain characteristic functions on P SL(2, R)/Γ.
The purpose of this article is to apply Zagier's theory to the case of a number field. Let
us briefly describe our results. Given a number filed K of degree n = r1 + 2r2 with ring of
integers o, there exists a Riemannian manifold H = (H2 )r1 × (H3 )r2 where the Hilbert
modular group Γ = P SL(2, o) acts properly and discontinuously. If the field K has class
number h, then the Hilbert modular orbifold M = H/Γ has h cusps and each cusp can
be parametrized by the standard cusp at infinity. From the geometry of M , it follows
that, for each cusp λ and q > 0, there exist a generalized closed horosphere B(q, λ)/Γλ
of dimension 2r1 + 3r2 − 1 and volume q −1 c, where c is a certain constant depending on
the field K. Let dυλ′ be the volume element of B(q, λ) and m(q, λ) be the probability
measure in M uniformly supported on B(q, λ)/Γλ with respect to dυλ′ . Let m be the
normalized Haar measure of M and mq = (m(q, λ1 ) + ... + m(q, λh ))/h. We have
Theorem 3. Let f be a smooth function on M with compact support. Then,
mq (f ) = m(f ) + o(q 1/2−ǫ )

(q → 0)

for all 0 < ǫ < 1/2.
We also give a generalization of Zagier's equivalence to the Riemann hypothesis and
prove the following assertion.
Theorem 4. The Riemann hypothesis for the Dedekind zeta function of K holds if and
only if for every smooth function f with compact support on M one has
mq (f ) = m(f ) + o(q 3/4−ǫ )

(q → 0)

for all 0 < ǫ < 1/4.
We prove these theorems following the work of Zagier and Sarnak. We study the Mellin
transform of q −1 mq and relate it to the Eisenstein series of the Hilbert modular orbifold
by means of the Rankin-Selberg theorem. The Eisenstein series, being divisible by the
Dedekind zeta function ζK (s) of the field, enables us to translate properties of ζK (s) into
properties of the Mellin transform of q −1 mq and, hence, properties of mq .

Let o be the ring of algebraic integers of K. The Hilbert modular group for the field
K is the group Γ = P SL(2, o) contained in P SL(2, K) ⊂ G. The action of Γ in H is
irreducible and, since o is a lattice, Γ is a discrete subgroup of G. Then a theorem of
Thurston [18, Ch. 13] implies that Γ acts properly and discontinuously on H and that
the quotient space
M = Γ\H
is a differentiable orbifold. It is called the Hilbert modular orbifold of the field K.

linear transformations. The cusps of Γ are the parabolic fixed points of Γ in P. They are
the image of the application P(K) → P given by α/β 7→ (α(i) /β (i) ). The group Γ acts

are in one-to-one correspondence with the elements of the ideal class group of K. To the
class of a fractional ideal a = hσ, ρi ⊂ K there corresponds the class of the cusp λ = σ/ρ.
In particular, to the identity in the ideal class group of K, that is to say, to the class of
